titleStmt.title: Wonderful and strange news from Scotland, being a true and full relation of a person lately deceased at the town of Dumfreez, whose corps could by no art of man, or strength of cattle, be removed from the place where it lay. And when the house wherein it was, was wholly burnt down to the ground, the body, coffin, and table whereon it stood, remained whole and untoucht, and so continues to the great astonishment of all spectators. / Faithfully communicated by a person of quality, in a letter from the said town of Dumfreez. Dated Septemb. 8. 1673.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 11 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 8 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

And when the house wherein it was, was wholly burnt down to the ground, the body, coffin, and table whereon it stood, remained whole and untoucht, and so continues to the great astonishment of all spectators. / Faithfully communicated by a person of quality, in a letter from the said town of Dumfreez. Dated Septemb. 8. 1673.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Curiosities and wonders -- Scotland -- Dumfries -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: Wonderful and Strange NEWS FROM Scotland, BEING A true and full Relation of a Per≈øon lately Decea≈øed at the Town of Dumfreez, who≈øe Corps could by no Art of Man, or Strength of Cattle, be Removed from the Place where it Lay.

And when the Hou≈øe wherein it was, was wholly Burnt down to the Ground, the Body, Coffin, and Table whereon it ≈øtood, remained Whole and ∆≤ntoucht, and ≈øo Continues to the great A≈øtoni≈øhment of all Spectators.

Faithfully Communicated by a Per≈øon of Quality, in a Letter from the ≈øaid Town of Dumfreez. Dated Septemb.
‚Ä¢ 8. 1673.
div.q: Great and Wonderful are the Works and Judgments of Jehovah; And who can find them out?
div.p: London, Printed for B. H. Anno Dom. 1673.

div.head: Wonderful and Unparralleld News from Scotland.
div.p: WHether tho≈øe St pendious Operations of Omnipotency, which dim-≈øighted Humanity admires by the Name of Miracles, and Infinite VVi≈ødom made u≈øe of for Confirming and Propagating Evangelical Truths in the In ‚Ä¢ ancy of the Ch ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ch, be yet totally Cea≈øed‚ñ™ is a Di≈øp ‚Ä¢ te too Ab≈øtru≈øe and Curio ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to be Di≈øcu≈ø≈øed (much le≈øs Determined) by our ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ er Pen: Yet this we mu≈øt declare, that the en≈ø ‚Ä¢ ing Na ‚Ä¢ rative carries with it ≈øo much of Rarity and VVonder, that had we not been well Satisfied in the worth and Credit of the Relaters we could not have pre≈øumed to Expo≈øe it thus publickly to the VVorld without much Caution and a large Apologie.

But being amply Convinced of the Truth of the thing as to matter of Fact, we conceive it a Duty rather than Crime, to Divulg ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ Regi≈øter ≈øo Eminent and Signal an Accident (or rather Di ‚Ä¢ pen≈øation of Providence) to the View of the pre≈øent Age an notice of Po≈øterity: Not that we are Ignorant how Obnox ‚Ä¢ ous generally (and ≈øometimes for good Rea≈øon) ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n Relations a ‚Ä¢ e to Su≈øpition and Cen≈øure, and how ready tho≈øe that Pride them≈øelves in being counted mighty VVits, as they make a Mock of Sin, are to turn the mo≈øt dreadfu ‚Ä¢ Judgments into Scoff and Drollery; from ≈øuch we may expect a Thou≈øand Intorrogatives. As wherefore? To what end? By what means? And how? could ≈øuch a ≈øtrange thing as this c ‚Ä¢ me to pa≈øs, &c.
But our An≈øwer is as ready, that, Had we de≈øigned to abu≈øe the World with a Fiction, an ordinary Invention might ≈øo Artificially have compo≈øed a Story, as might have been Plau≈øible enough to An≈øwer all the Nice Scurtinies of their wanton Imaginations: But that's a Liberty we dare not take, and only ≈øhall Nakedly ≈øet forth the Truth of the thing as it happened, and leave each Reader to make his own Glo≈øs or Comment on it afterwards as he plea≈øes.

IN the Town of Dumfreez (Situate in Galloway, on the South of Scotland, near the Mar≈øhes or Borders) there lately Dwelt an Antient man, of an ordinary Fortune, who in the ≈øecond week of this la≈øt September, happened to fall very Sick, his Di≈øtemper ≈øeemed to be only a violent Feaver; nor was there any thing Extraordinary in it, but this: That as he was Seized with it, he declared to his VVife and Neighbours, that he ≈øhould certainly Die of that Sickne≈øs, which continually prevailing again≈øt Langui≈øhing Nature, ≈øoon per≈øwaded them al≈øo to be of the ≈øame Opinion. But the very day before he departed this Life, he charged his wife to get him Buried within Three Hours after he ≈øhould be Dead. This his ≈øorrowful wife little Regarded, thinking them only to be Extravagant words that proceeded from the Di≈øtemperature of his Brain: which he ob≈øorving, Repeated the ≈øame Injunction ≈øeveral times, both to her, and diver≈øe others of his Friends; very ≈øolemnly adding, that unle≈øs they did ≈øo Bury him in that ≈øhort ≈øpace, they ≈øhould never be able afterwards to bear away, or remove his Body. They askt him often, what he meant? And why he ≈øhould ≈øay ≈øo? But could procure no An≈øwer from him, but this, with many deep ≈øighs, It would be ≈øo.

The Malignity of the Di≈øea≈øe was now arrived to the height, that Nature overpoured, could no longer-re≈øi≈øt, ≈øo that on the 28th. of the ≈øaid Month of September la≈øt this poor Creature was forced to quit the Stage of this Tran ‚Ä¢ itory Life; Dying in a calm and ordinary Temper, without declaring much his hopes, or betraying any ≈øymptoms of di≈øpair.

His enfranchi≈øed Soul had no ≈øooner quitted the Pri≈øon of his Body and was wafted to Eternity, but his Friends remembring his Charge of being ≈øpeedily Buried, re≈øolve to make a Truce with their Griefs, and not ‚Ä¢ t ≈øtill ≈øtupified with an unprofitable Sorrow, but rather execute as fa≈øt as they can his dying Commands in that particular: To this purpo≈øe a Coffin is immediately ≈øent for, and the Corps as ≈øoon as ≈øaid forth put into it, being placed on a Table in a Ground round, Neighbours are invited, and all preparation made to inter him that very Night; but the three hours were Elap≈øt, It being almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible to provide all things in ≈øo ≈ømall a time. At la≈øt the Company being met with Charitable intentions to bear and Accompany the body to it's long home, in the place Sacrated & ≈øet a part for that purpo≈øe, which was above half a Mile di≈øtant, when they went to take up the Coffin. Behold! It would not ≈øtir, four or five men confe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves too weak, and then the whole Company add their helping hands but to no purpo≈øe, the Coffin ≈øeems fixed to the Table to grow out of the Ground, rather than ≈øtand there, ≈øo that neither one nor the other could by all their ≈øtrength be removed, or ≈øtirred in the lea≈øt.

This accident a≈øtoni≈øhes all the Company, who having wearied them≈øelves to no purpo≈øe, repair at night to their re≈øpective Habitations fill'd with Admiration, and leaving the di≈øcon≈øolate Widdow and her poor Children, in the Hou≈øe equally ore whe ‚Ä¢ m'd with Grief, and affrighted with this new kind of Prodigy.

Next day New Coun≈øells were taken about carrying away this Corps, Since the Coffin could not be ≈øtirred, nor the Table moved by ≈øtrength of Man, they re≈øolve at la≈øt to try what may be done with that of Cattel; and to come at it conveniently are forced to pull down a wall and one ≈øide of the Hou≈øe, which being done, they fa≈øten ≈øeveral Teems both of Oxen and Hor≈øes to the Coffin ≈øometimes, and ≈øometimes to the Table: But both remain ≈øtill as fixed and immoveable as a Rock, and which was remarkable though the ≈øtrength of the Cattle broke, mo≈øt of their Tackling, yet neither the Coffin nor the Table, received the lea≈øt prejudice.

They then e≈ø≈øayed to open the Coffin and take out the Body, but that neither could be done; ≈øo that at length di≈øpairing of any ≈øucce≈øs, t ‚Ä¢ ey give over attempting any thing further, but a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ the poor Woman and her C ‚Ä¢ ildren, to get out of the Hou≈øe, and ≈øo ‚Ä¢ eave it ≈øtanding; which they did accordingly, and carried all their moveable Goods to another Hou≈øe in the Town.

Thus the Corps ≈øtood in the f ‚Ä¢ r≈øa ‚Ä¢ en Tenement for two or three days, and had as many wondring Pilgr ‚Ä¢ ms to vi≈øit it, out of Curo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ty‚ñ™ as Super≈øtition in Fo ‚Ä¢ eign parts carries to the Tomb of ≈øome Celebrated
„Äà‚óä„Äâ .

At la≈øt the Land Lord of the Hou≈øe who dwelt ≈øome Miles di≈øtant, hearing great R ‚Ä¢ port of this Prodigy, came to ≈øee it; and fin ‚Ä¢ ing ‚Ä¢ ll things as we have r ‚Ä¢ lated, becau≈øe his Hou≈øe by this means wa ‚Ä¢ rendred Incapable of being Tenanted (for who would willingly dwell in a Charnel Hou≈øe) and that it was before old and ruinous, re≈øolves wholly to demoli≈øh it, and build a new one in the place, and that he might be rid of this unparalleld Tomb, concludes to ≈øet the Hou≈øe on Fire, not do ‚Ä¢ bting but thereby the Coffin, Table, and Corps would tog ‚Ä¢ ther with the re≈øt be ≈øo ‚Ä¢ n reduced to A≈øhes; but he promi ‚Ä¢ ed him≈øe ‚Ä¢ f too much, for when they had ≈øet ‚Ä¢ he Hou≈øe all on Flames, and the ≈øame was wholly Burnt down to the Ground. The Coffin and Table ≈øtood as before, whole firm and untoucht.

Seeing all ways fail, ≈øome Friends of the decea≈øed, after the Hou≈øe was Burnt took the pains to ca≈øt up Earth ‚Ä¢ bout Table, and at la≈øt have cover'd the Coffin with that Bank which yet can never hide the ≈øtrangene≈øs of the thing, b ‚Ä¢ t that it will remain a wonder and a Rid ‚Ä¢ le to fu ‚Ä¢ ure Generations. And ≈øuch we leave it, without any impertinent di ‚Ä¢ qui ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tion after the Cau≈øe of ≈øo Admirab ‚Ä¢ e Phen ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ non, or Saucy prying into the Eternal Dooms-day Book of Providence; which ≈øometimes for Rea≈øons only known to its infinite Wi≈ødom ≈øuffers wonderful things to come to pa≈øs, and often (as in the well known Ca≈øe of Lots Wife turned into a la≈øting Pillar of Salt) ≈øets up amazing Monuments of Divine Ju≈øtice for Sin, to warn
and deter others from ≈øuch Crimes. Let not the Reader bu≈øie him≈øelf ≈øo much in gue ‚Ä¢ ≈øing what notorious off ‚Ä¢ nce could cau≈øe the Infliction of ≈øo ≈øtrange a puni≈øhment, or branding the Decea≈øed Party with har≈øh and unwarrantable (becau≈øe uncharitable) Cen≈øures, as to forget his own Duty, which is to become more Holy and more Humble, by ≈øuch dreadful Examples. And ≈øo to work out ‚Ä¢ h ‚Ä¢ Sa ‚Ä¢ vation with Fe ‚Ä¢ r and T ‚Ä¢ em ‚Ä¢ ling, That when him≈øelf ≈øhall be Summoned by Death, however Providence ≈øhall di≈øpo≈øe of his Body, His Soul may be received into the Man≈øions of Bli≈øs and Glory.
IF the Reader doubts of the Truth of this Matter, He may Repair to the≈øe Per≈øons following,

list.item: Mr. Edward Crouch, Living in Cow-Lane.
Mr. Humphry Eeds, Living in Princes-≈øtreet.
Mr. Stephen Harwood, Living on the back≈øide of the Exchange.
Mr. Edward Barker, Living in Dunnings-Alley, without Bi≈øhops-Gate.
Mr. John Ames, Living at Tobie's Coffee-hou≈øe, near Pie-Corner.
